title: [K-12] RME-Based Classroom Research Workshop for High School Mathematics Teachers' Professional Development

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of high school mathematics curriculum and basic teaching methodologies, basic awareness of Realistic Mathematics Education (RME) concepts
context.additional_context: Participants collaborate in real-time via Zoom within smartphone-based limited technology environments, submitting final outputs through project-based assessments

learning_goals: Learners select three real-life contextual math problems (e.g., shopping discounts, sports statistics analysis) following RME (Realistic Mathematics Education) principles (phenomenon-guidance-scaffolding-vertical mathematization) and draft a lesson module applying a 5-step instructional design process (problem presentation-investigation-discussion-summarization-evaluation).

Teachers collaborate with three peers via LSLC (Learning Study Learning Community) protocols (biweekly online meetings, shared resource platform) to improve a unit-level lesson plan and establish an implementation plan meeting ≥4 of 5 peer-review checklist criteria.

Learners use multi-tiered assessments (3 formative quizzes + 1 summative project) post-RME lessons to demonstrate ≥80% science concept mastery and ≥2-level improvement (5-point scale) in problem-solving skills.

resources: LSLC (Learning Support Learning Community) Operation Template
constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
